Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

A spam filter is a computer program designed to distinguish legitimate e-mail from spam (undesirable e-mail). The technology department at a large company plans to investigate the performance of two different spam filters (A and B) across the e-mail inboxes of its employees.

A random sample of <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> employee e-mail inboxes was selected from all employee e-mail inboxes from the company. E-mails entering each inbox were passed through both spam filters and the difference in filter performance, measured by the difference in the proportion of e-mails correctly filtered, was recorded for each inbox at the end of two weeks.

The histogram shows the distribution of the differences in filter performance (A minus B) for the <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> e-mail inboxes.

(a) Describe the distribution of the differences in filter performance for the <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> e-mail inboxes.

The technology department will use a hypothesis test, at <math alttext="alpha equals 0.05" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, to determine whether the sample data provide convincing statistical evidence that Spam Filter A has a greater filter performance than Spam Filter B. Let <math alttext="mu sub difference" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the mean difference in filter performance (A minus B) for all e-mail inboxes at the company that could be passed through the two spam filters. The hypotheses are:

<math alttext="h sub 0 colon mu sub difference equals 0, h sub a colon mu sub difference is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><msub><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mstyle><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace linebreak="newline"></mspace><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><msub><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn><mspace linebreak="newline"></mspace></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

(b) Identify a feature of the distribution of the sample differences in filter performance that might raise concerns about whether the sampling distribution of <math alttext="x bar sub difference" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is approximately normal, and explain why it is reasonable to conclude that the sampling distribution of <math alttext="x bar sub difference" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is approximately normal in this case.

Assuming all conditions for inference were met, the hypothesis test was conducted and resulted in a test statistic of <math alttext="t is approximately equal to 3.133" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>≈</mo><mn>3.133</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(c) Based on the results of the hypothesis test, what conclusion can be made about the two spam filters? Justify your answer.

An employee in the technology department believes that filter performance is related to e-mail volume (the number of e-mails an inbox received). The scatterplots show, by spam filter, the relationship between e-mail volume and filter performance for the <math alttext="35" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> e-mail inboxes.

(d) Describe and compare the association between e-mail volume and filter performance for the two spam filters.

(e) Suppose an e-mail inbox is randomly selected from those in the study. For which spam filter (A or B) is there a greater probability of selecting an inbox that has a filter performance of at least <math alttext="0.9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> given an e-mail volume of more than <math alttext="150" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>150</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>? Interpret what this means in the context of the study.

(f) Provide a recommendation to the technology department that describes how inboxes should be assigned to Spam Filter A or Spam Filter B based on e-mail volume if the goal is to assign the filter with the greater filter performance. Justify your answer based on the two scatterplots.
